title: Between 15 September 2020 and 30 November 2020, will a country cease to formally recognize Taiwan?
preds: Updating due to the timeframe and the fact that there seems to be little diplomatic movement, although China has increased its military activity vis-a-vis Tawain over the last two months.  Other countries may wait to make any moves to see what the Biden administration will do on Taiwan. https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/11/10/biden-taiwan-election-trump-china/
Final update as question closes in two days.  No change.
Fully decremented for time remaining.  I will stand at 3%.

Sometimes it's useful to get in on a question toward the end when it's something you haven't researched before to get a feel for it. It seems to me that given the aggressive position on China by the out-going US admin, any country considering this would wait until the next admin to avoid any last minute retribution.
i did not properly factor in time constraint (Nov 30) into my initial forecast

There are 15 countries in the sample. The joint probability assuming 95% survival is around 45%. I adjust that slightly because I believe there is some path dependence. Overall, 40% Yes summarises well my conviction level.
update with two weeks left.  The recent signing of the RECP is interesting, but not enough to turn another country around in a short amount of time.

Updated 20201115 "...will a country cease to recognize Taiwan?" On the assumption that the question is applied to a country that currently has formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan and will break the diplomatic relations before 30 Nov 2020. Two high level visits by USA politicians has certainly raised the profile of Taiwan in main stream media.

There are currently no geopolitical events that would threaten Taiwan being recognized as a country. It's possible, but unlikely to happen within the next 2 weeks.

As certainty about who will be in charge in US may stay unclear for some time, bargaining with either Trump or Biden administrations will take longer than timeframe, so while it may happen, I think not until end of november.

There are no elections taking place before 30 November that could significantly impact this other than our own.

“[América Crece] is an umbrella concept through which the U.S. has been trying to relaunch its attempts to promote private sector investment in critical sectors in Latin America, in energy and infrastructure, to counter Chinese investment in those sectors,” said Bruno Binette, an analyst with the Washington D.C. based think tank The Dialogue.
[...]
As part of the initiative, individual governments of Latin America sign Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs) with the DFC, laying out areas of focus for which types of projects will be included in the funding. The Governments of Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador have each signed on for $1 billion each in US government funding for infrastructure projects as part of América Crece.
[...]
Over thirty years after the end of the Cold War, the region once again finds itself in a macro-geopolitical conflict. Faced with increased investment by Chinese firms in the region, the Trump administration launched América Crece to advance the interests of US corporations.  “There is clearly a growing competition between the United States and China,” Binette said. “But it is very problematic for countries to choose between the United States and China.” Simply put, the United States sees China as a threat in Latin America.  In recent years, the United States has regularly warned business leaders in the region against doing business with China. In spite of this, China represents an ideal business partner for cash starved states in the region. Since 2010, companies associated with the Chinese government have averaged 10 billion dollars of annual investment in Latin America per year. These investments have gone to many sectors and industries, particularly infrastructure projects, mining and oil drilling, and other energy projects.  “It is all about the availability of capital, quick loans, a willingness to navigate Latin America’s context of corruption and rule of law that would deter companies from Europe and the United States,” Binette said. “For China, everything is part of the package. They offer the countries an attractive package. Governments can offer immediate results.” “The United States cannot rival China,” he said. The Chinese option has opened new options for investments, leading Latin American governments to distance themselves from Taiwan as part of the “One China” policy, and grow closer to Beijing. In Central America, Costa Rica, Panamá, El Salvador and the Dominican Republic have ended diplomatic ties with Taiwan in return for development funds from China. Only Guatemala, Honduras, Belize, and Nicaragua continue to maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan, which means that they mostly don’t trade with China.
[...]
Both parties in the US continue to see Chinese investments in the region as a threat. In September 2020, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee launched the America Labor, Economic competitiveness, Alliances, Democracy and Security (America LEADS) Act to counter Chinese influence. The LEADS Act is designed to invest in American competitiveness; support American alliances and partners; restore and advance a values-centered foreign policy; and ensure China pays a price for what senators argue are predatory actions.
https://towardfreedom.org/story/america-crece-washingtons-new-investment-push-in-latin-america/ ___ " It was an unusually noticeable 109th Taiwan National Day in India, with posters and flags hung outside the Chinese embassy by a ruling party member and Taiwan’s president thanking “dear friends in India” for sending wishes for their annual celebration.
[...]
The other countries to which she had expressed appreciation through her Twitter timeline were St Kitts and Nevis and Honduras. Both these countries are among the 15 nations who have full diplomatic relations with Taiwan."

When I last considered this question, I was wondering (based on my base rate estimate that Taiwan seemed to shed nearly one diplomatic ally per year, on average) if a country had already ceased diplomatic recognition in 2020.    Having tried to establish an outside view, I turned to a colleague who works in the international affairs community and who follows Asia, to find out more about that and get the Inside View.    Here is what he said: "Taiwan didn’t lose any partners in 2020 but I think lost two in the Pacific alone in 2019.  I’d say the rate of loss is accelerating, as Beijing gets better at peeling away, and then keeping away, partners.  I can’t speak to the Latin American partners.  Of the four Pacific partners, Palau and the Marshalls are probably secure because they’re in free association with the U.S.  Tuvalu is probably okay.  Nauru is in my opinion the shakiest; they have zero natural resources, virtually no economy, and the island is barely livable, so they could be bought by Beijing probably without a ton of trouble.  But no one is likely to dump Taiwan in the next six weeks." The logic of my initial analysis was: if Taiwan typically loses recognition by one country per year, and they have not yet lost an ally in 2020, they are due to lose one, thus 90% probability of Yes.    However, the fine grained analysis of my colleague, coupled with the fact that the time horizon for the event to happen is now quite short (six weeks), I am revising my forecast to only 5% Yes.
- As the deadline draws closer it is less likely a country will cease to recognize Taiwan.

China could use the upcoming 70th anniversary of the Korean War (or the "War to Resist U.S. Aggression and Aid Korea") to make another diplomatic and propaganda push. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/05/world/asia/china-propaganda-united-states.html

Decreasing forecast by 2 pts due to the passage of time and the lack of publicly available indicators that any of the states that recognize Taiwan have plans to reverse course by 30 Nov.  While the Vatican has made some overtures toward China, it has stated that the arrangement is religious, not diplomatic in nature (China has 12 million Catholics).  The Vatican's stated intent is to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan.  https://nationalinterest.org/feature/can-united-states-and-vatican-help-taiwan-avoid-war-170031

At the latest U.N. General Assembly session at the end of September 2020, many of the countries who still recognize Taiwan spoke in support of the island nation's sovereignty. Based on reports from the Taipei Times, only the Vatican has yet to voice support for Taiwan this year, and I believe under the circumstances in China with the increasingly oppressive behavior of the Chinese Communist party specifically as it relates to suppression of freedoms in Hong Kong, I think the Vatican changing course within the month is virtually non-existent. Quotes from the Taipei Times include the following: "All of Taiwan’s allies except for the Vatican have written letters to UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres this year in support of the nation, Ministry of Foreign Affairs Joanne Ou (歐江安) said. Ten countries — Belize, Eswatini, Haiti, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, St Kitts and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, and Tuvalu — signed a joint letter to Guterres, Ou said. However, the letter has yet to be delivered, due to stringent COVID-19 prevention measures at the UN, she said. The other four — Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Paraguay — have written to Guterres individually, Ou said."
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----
"Belizean Minister of Foreign Affairs Wilfred Elrington and Nicaraguan Minister of Foreign Affairs Denis Moncada Colindres spoke up for Taiwan on Tuesday, the last day of the annual debate that began on Tuesday last week. “Belize calls for the full participation of Taiwan in the UN system,” he said, adding that Taiwan possesses the capacity to do so as exemplified by its successful and effective approach to the COVID-19 pandemic, and its assistance to allied and other countries"
- 8 Weeks to go, no newsworthy events this week.

https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2020/10/01/2003744416 "Twelve of Taiwan’s 15 diplomatic allies voiced support for the nation’s bid to join the UN during the general debate of the 75th UN General Assembly. 
[...]
The three allies that did not mention Taiwan were Guatemala, Honduras and the Vatican.
[...]
Ten countries — Belize, Eswatini, Haiti, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, St Kitts and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, and Tuvalu — signed a joint letter to Guterres, Ou said.
However, the letter has yet to be delivered, due to stringent COVID-19 prevention measures at the UN, she said.
The other four — Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Paraguay — have written to Guterres individually, Ou said." Leaving the Holy See out of consideration, there are obviously Guatemala and Honduras, who did not speak up for Taiwan's right for statehood and thus seem to be wary and maybe afraid of consequences in relations to and maybe depending on trade with PR China. The reluctance of Paraguay and Nicaragua to sign a joint letter to Guterres may also be a signal for cloudy or meaningless relations to RoC/Taiwan, or having no ambitions to spoil relations to PR China. Adding Paraguay and Nicaragua at 50% each, I extract three candidate allies that may cease to formally recognize Taiwan in the near future.

Updating my response after looking at Jtrusz's analysis.  The four nations most likely to be swayed by increased PRC pressure are Taiwan's four remaining Pacific allies - the Marshall Islands, Palau, Nauru and Tuvalu.  All currently seem resistant to changes in their diplomatic relations.  Moreover, these nations looked to strike some form of formal alliance to unite against those nations that defected to the PRC in Oceana/Micronesia.  Moreover, Taiwan has used the COVID-19 crisis as an opportunity to support those nations that formally recognize it.
Adjusting for passage of time.  I don't know where the time goes, but it doesn't come here.

Lowering the percentage given the timeline.   Additional information from research is provided.  A total of seven countries broke diplomatic ties with Taiwan after President Tsai was elected in January 2016.  Even though two countries severed ties last year, there has been no indication that any other countries are planning to sever ties with her re-election in January 2020.  The Chinese do have "race to zero" campaign to sever all diplomatic ties with Taiwan so more countries will switch to the PRC over time as they apply additional pressure.  Although the current 15 countries that have diplomatic ties with Taiwan provide trade, international support, and legitimacy benefits, countries like the US, UK, and Japan (informally aligned with Taiwan) provide greater benefit and voice to Taiwan than the other smaller 15 countries still in the fight.  I am assuming that the countries still maintaining diplomatic ties with Taiwan are also smaller countries, that want to maintain a voice in the international community and this provides that avenue, and worth keeping.  Worth keeping a closer eye on other countries in East Asia and the Pacifica and potential inducement measures going on there from China's "race to zero" to see if another country will fall in the next few months.

After continued research, I have not found any additional evidence that a country that formally recognizes Taiwan will cease to do so in the near future. As a result, I am adjusting my probability down by one percent. I do not expect a country to make such a decision in the next few weeks, especially given the uncertainty around political and possible financial ramifications (impending elections in US and Taiwan) of that choice taken right now.

A good challenge. One that should make us examine our own worldviews before deciding. In the past, switches of allegiance to or from Taiwan have most often been decided by who pays the most in subsidies and/or fishing rights. For example, a low income nation hit by a severe hurricane or typhoon hitting would be vulnerable to financial largesse with strings attached. I make that twelve out of the fifteen exposed to this kind of pressure alone. And it is hurricane season, which makes this an interesting time of year.

My original forecast had the probability much higher (north of 60%).  However, this was based on an internal view of the issue vice external - taking the frequency of times that a country actually changes its relationship with China - once every year or so. The span of time is very narrow, making the probability lower. Historically, notwithstanding the current Arab Israeli peace agreements (driven by delivering on an election promise) nations will wait out the US election to see who they will/will not have to deal with as a result of any major diplomatic change. International surveys reflect negatively on the US administration and this amplifies the "wait and see" phenomenon around US elections.

I misunderstood this statement.  It is not common for a country to change they way they recognize a nation.  Without any major action, I don't believe it is likely that a new nation will cease to recognize ROC (Taiwan) in favor of PRC.
Its been a year since the last 2 countries and I cannot find any evidence of a new change now

Fifteen countries (including the Holy See) have formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China (ROC). Since 1999, thirteen countries ceased recognition of ROC in favor of establishing full relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC). Given the steady success of the PRC's inducements to drop recognition of the ROC, it is possible another country will do so before November 30, 2020. However, the Trump administration has stepped up public displays of support for the ROC with widely publicized cabinet and sub-cabinet level visits to Taiwan in summer 2020. HHS secretary Azar was the highest level official USG visitor to Taiwan since 1979. This very public support may reduce the chances of defection in the short-term. Likewise, the PRC's apparent suppression of reporting about COVID-19 in the early days of the pandemic may have reduced its appeal, but that is difficult to quantify. It seems possible but unlikely a country will stop recognizing the ROC before November 30, 2020.
Easy tool for China to use to counter US

- 1990 28 countries , 2019 15 countries  (.43 a year)
- 45 day period (.12) 
- .43 * .12 = 5%
The list is already pretty sparse and obscure, I'm not sure any listed are under pressure or stand to gain from dropping off any time soon.

Not very likely given that China is somewhat on its heals after mismanaging COVID and passing the National Security Law affecting Hong Kong.  China has received a lot of bad publicity lately which impacts its sense of legitimacy as a world power.  Therefore, China won't be aggressive in pushing further countries to dump Taiwan relations.  In addition, the remaining 15 countries with diplomatic ties to Taiwan are small so not of significant concern to China; however, this also means that China could easily threaten or bribe (BRI) the small nations if the US or other world leaders don't offer support.
I do not see any catalyst for change

The PRC have flipped 1 or 2 countries a year since 2016 and there are similar nations among the 15 that recognize ROC. So, if we assign a 80% (assumed) for all of 2020, a 10 week period results in 15%, given the Covid may put additional pressure on nations, we can bump this estimate up slightly. (Note: my gut says 10% on this question)

While the chances may increase long-term, a shift is unlikely during the next 70 days.  Currently only 15/193 (roughly 8%) UN-organized states recognize Taiwan as the ROC.  It's been approximately one year since any state has swapped its allegiance to the PRC.   While the U.S. has not changed its position, it has increased engagement with Taiwan, including the first cabinet-level visit since 1979.  This may provide the smaller countries that currently recognize Taiwan with more cover to maintain their positions.  Plus, UNGA is not in person this year, which would have been an opportune venue for the PRC to pressure states.

The chances grow more likely over the long-term as China continues to grow its power in the Region without being checked by the international community.  I don't foresee another country making this decision until their is greater clarity in trade relations between the US/China, the US shift to the Pacific as a whole, impacts of COVID, and fallout from the Hong Kong NSL.

This just a starting hypothesis - will update once I do more research. Before conducting any research, I'll assign the same probability of breaking/not breaking diplomatic ties to each of the 15 countries that have diplomatic relations with Taiwan. Doing this Bayesian-style, I would stake $100 that any one country would not break diplomatic relations, and expect to receive $1 if I'm correct. That makes the odds of any one country not breaking 100 to 1, and probability of not breaking ~ 0.990099 And then here are the calculations that follow:
P(1 country not breaking) = 0.990099
P(all countries not breaking) = 0.990099 ^ 15 
P(at least one countries breaking) = 1 - (0.990099 ^ 15) = 0.1387

I think the a decision like this is probably not high on the list of issues that the remaining 15 countries (including the Vatican See) is planning on addressing given Covid.  A deal like this probably involves some negotiation, more likely in face-to-face deals where China can seduce their counterparts with promises of largesse or lucrative trade and support deals. Additionally with the draconian new laws imposed by China on Hong Kong in June of 2020, that might make countries a bit wary of a deal that would give that tyranny more legitimacy. The length of the window seems rather small  as well. The counter to that would be that the economies in a couple of these countries, due to Covid's impact, could be or get so bad that a deal with China could be too good to be true at this time.  Additionally, China feels like it's willing to pay for it's friends and you recall the old saying, "never let a crisis go to waste".

The last two countries to stop recognizing Taiwan, Kiribati and Soloman, had economic pressures from China.  With everything going on between China and Hong Kong, I don't see China making a power play against Taiwan.

China is becoming a pariah due to the coronavirus. Their economy is in trouble, and I recently watch a couple of Youtube videos which imply that China's economic problems could threaten the CCP. Saber rattling with Taiwan could distract the Chinese people from their problems so I give a 15% chance that China could strong-arm someone to renounce Taiwan.

Base rate is around 1/yr. However China is consistent and constant in suppressing political, legal, and commercial independence of Taiwan so it is likely China Foreign Affairs officials continuously work to have diplomatic relations of Taiwan dropped. Two critical points during this forecast window.  Vatican renewal of agreement with China in Oct 2020 and US Presidential election.  Vatican agreement will likely put recognition of Taiwan at risk.
- In July, the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post quoted a Vatican source as saying that the Holy See could even move its embassy from Taiwan to the mainland. "Taiwan should not be offended if the embassy in Taipei is moved back to its original address in Beijing,” the Vatican source was quoted saying. The US presidential election likely moves the risk in the opposite direction. Current administration is taking a multi-faceted approach to engage and recognize Taiwan. Similar to recent agreement between UAE and Israel, the administration could be working to make a policy announcement to garner favorable foreign policy media before the election. This would put pressure on current countries to maintain diplomatic recognition. With outside view/base-rate 1/yr and no losses this year I'll start with 50% during this timeframe and then reduce by approximately half to account for pressure created by current US behavior.

Taiwan is recognized by about 7% of the United Nations member states.  There are highly likely a number of those nations that can place reliance for support in a state other than PRC so would not have to cease formally recognizing Taiwan in lieu of receiving support from PRC in areas such as agriculture, healthcare, & education. It's unlikely any landlocked countries or central American would need to change their position in the following month and likely the central American countries have a heavy American influence due to proximity to the mainland.  Timing is the main unknown in this one. It is highly likely at least 3 of the 14 (7%) UN member states will at some stage in the near future cease to recognize Taiwan.  If the original 14 UN member states still recognizing Taiwan were considered 100% then the starting point would be 21% probability for only 3 of those states. Given the time frame (and island time for decisions being formalized), I have taken an additional 9% off.  The UN member states likely to make this decision sooner are Nauru, Palau, and Tuvalu. Nauru is probably the least likely of these due to the reliance and presence of the Australian government to maintain relations.

The US doesn't so maybe more countries will out of spite towards the US (Iran, Turkey, Russia, cuba). Or maybe Chinese regional hegemony will assert itself more forcefully. This is an interesting question and I'll be interested to continue following.

With the world falling back into a more severe pandemic mode the likelihood that China will receive additional support from any other countries is limited, therefore support for Taiwan is not likely to fall at this time.
The PRC continues to expand influence, but most likely this will not result in further countries ceasing to recognize the RoC.

For a rough first stab at my forecast, I researched how many countries cut diplomatic recognition of Taiwan over a given time span in order to get a sense of the rate of Taiwan's loss of its allies.  
Between 2001 and 2020, 17 countries dropped diplomatic recognition, so that's 17 countries in 19 years, or rate of losing .89 ally countries per year - nearly one country per year.
So if Taiwan is shedding allies at a rate of nearly one country per year, they are due to lose another friend in 2020 if they have not already done so.
So next step would be to figure out whether Taiwan has already lost an ally in 2020.   So far I have not found info indicating that a country renounced diplomatic ties in 2020, yet, so that would mean that Taiwan is due to lose another country this year.    Therefore I think the probability is high; I'll say 90%.   
(If I uncover info that Taiwan lost a diplomatic ally already in 2020, I'll revise the probability closer to zero). If I were asked to name which country would drop Taiwan, Eswatini (formerly Swaziland) looks likely:
https://thediplomat.com/2020/02/report-beijing-ups-pressure-on-taipeis-sole-remaining-african-diplomatic-partner/ If I continue my research on this I'll work on figuring out exactly how many partners Taiwan lost per year in the last 20 years, to see if there are patterns regarding the rate of loss of friends speeding up or slowing down.  
I'll also look at the list of remaining friends and see if there's info that indicates whether specific countries are likely to peel away.   This article names Haiti, Paraguay, and St Vincent Grenadines as being likeliest to dump Taiwan: https://focustaiwan.tw/politics/202005210012  although Paraguay voted not to sever relations in April 2020.

This is a broad question.  I say China already fails to recognize Taiwan as its own country now.  If the question were rewritten to include "...a country other than China..." then I would swing closer to the middle.

Using one of the several good forecasts on this thread to date to get an anchor of 17% (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1135422)  Then uprating slightly, in the expectation that during or after the US visit China may look for a retaliatory move and exert pressure (financial etc.) on some more countries to cease relations.

Very small timeframe. Despite the PRC's desperate vie for influence, I can't realistically see it happening within 45 days particularly before the US election. 
However, many pacific nations are in the tank because of the tourism decline, the alluring promise of a Chinese investment glut may entice them to switch allegiance. 
Will keep an eye on this.

combining baseline 17% https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1135422
and reducing by 3%  because possibility of tactical waiting of countries on expected US foreign relations post election https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1134948
In the long run, China will minnow out most. Probably less likely in this 45 day period.

It looks like there are about 16 countries left that still have a diplomatic relationship with the ROC.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_diplomatic_relations_of_the_Republic_of_China
In the last 5 years, there were 7 countries that ceased relationships with the ROC, pretty steadily 1-2 per year. That means on average, the chance of a country leaving in a given month was 7 / 5 / 12 = 0.12 = 12%. Given that there are now 7 fewer countries, its slightly less likely in a given month that we'll see a country leave per month (adjusted 0.12 to 0.08). Practically, I suspect China is actively working to convince all these countries to cease relationships in exchange for better trade agreements or other financial incentives (eg. credit lines). All the remaining countries are small and easily influenceable by a global superpower. With 2.5 months left to go before the deadline, the chance is 8% x 2.5 = 20%

From 2015-2019, only in 2015 did no country cease recognizing Taiwan ->
X = Likelihood of a country ceasing to recognize Taiwan in 2020 = 80% = 4/5 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_diplomatic_relations_of_the_Republic_of_China However, in 2020 no country has yet to and I am asked if a country will do so before December 2020, therefore I will update X ->
X = Likelihood of a country ceasing to recognize Taiwan between Mid September and before December 2020  
X = 17% = 80% * (12-8.5) / 12 - 80% * (12-11)/12
While possible, it seems unlikely at the moment where China is not exactly winning over hearts and minds.
Very few countries left and with the questions tight timeframe the probability is low.

Financial incentives appear to be a significant driver behind a country's choice to formally recognize Taiwan.  Given the impending elections both in Taiwan and the US, it seems unlikely that a additional countries would cease to recognize Taiwan right now. Countries that formally recognize Taiwan may choose to wait for the election outcome and evaluate what it could mean for financial incentives, and thus continued recognition of Taiwan vs. China. If this question were longer-term, however, I think that more countries will respond to China's offers of money or other resources. http://www.internationalaffairs.org.au/australianoutlook/does-it-matter-if-taiwan-loses-formal-recognition/
https://thediplomat.com/2019/09/taiwan-loses-2-diplomatic-allies-wins-us-support-ahead-of-crucial-presidential-election/

Increase probability since Paraguay has active discussion on this topic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paraguay%E2%80%93Taiwan_relations#cite_note-19. US puts pressure on China by supplying weapons to Taiwan. China might make a move by pressuring other countries to cease to recognize Taiwan.

The research shows that of the 15 countries that still hold diplomatic relations with Taiwan, only the Holy See (Vatican) could or would not be coerced by the People’s Republic of China that is using its economic power to freeze Taiwan from the World Stage.
The remaining 14 countries are either small, relatively poor or both and susceptible to the carrot and stick approach of hard and soft power that highly transactional.
Also, the countries that are in the same geographic location have succumbed to the short-term economic benefits, plus the debt of an economic superpower.
Therefore, any on country could be persuaded to alter its allegiance to Beijing, especially given the crisis created by Covid-19 and the potential financial and medical assistance that may be offered.
The world is distracted by the US Elections, Covid-19, Brexit and China could use this period to gain extra leverage / advantage with the remaining countries that remain in diplomatic relations with Taiwan. China has an obsession with regaining what it sees as its rightful property of Taiwan and has a sole aim to take it over.
This question is framed for an extremely tight time frame, so I suggest that no country will achieve a diplomatic change by then, but in the longer term, almost certainly. https://www.lowyinstitute.org/the-interpreter/who-will-abandon-taiwan-next  https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2020/05/17/why-taiwan-is-not-recognised-on-the-international-stage  https://www.euronews.com/2019/09/05/solomon-islands-to-sever-ties-with-taiwan-shift-alliance-to-beijing
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-diplomacykiribati/taiwan-says-china-lures-kiribati-with-airplanes-after-losing-another-ally-idUSKBN1W50DI  https://www.usip.org/publications/2020/07/rising-china-has-pacific-islands-its-sights  https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3030495/taiwans-last-four-pacific-allies-pledge-their-loyalty-after  https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3085449/who-coronavirus-meeting-highlights-taipeis-last-african-ally  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7102519/  https://sentinel.tw/taiwans-central-america-dilemma/  https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/taiwans-last-stand-in-south-america/  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7102519/

I am giving a relatively high probability for this to happen: since we have had "Xi Jinping's thought for socialism with chinese characteristics for a new era" (I hope I did I not forget some part), the number of countries switching their recognition from the ROC to the PRC as the true and only China has increased. Simply take a look at wikipedia here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Taiwan#Relations_switched_from_the_ROC_to_the_PRC and order the list by year: 2016 one country, 2017 one, 2018 had two countries switching and 2019 two. So far 2020 is passing uneventfully without a new switch, and I am sure that the emperor is not amused. In a time frame of 75 days this does not look terribly probable. But it might happen that China will have a vaccine passing a Phase III soon (be it by fair or foul means) and that they will begin a bit of vaccine diplomacy (if they did this with mask, why not with vaccines?). Besides, maybe a bit of supply chain disruption will make it sure that these pesky Americans or Europeans do not have enough vaccines to do vaccine diplomacy. Last, they have already announced that the Chinese population should not expect to be totally vaccinated. So maybe we should be prepared for the miracles of vaccine diplomacy. Now, being serious: the time frame of the question is 2.5 months (a bit more than 1/5 of a year), the base rate might be 1 or 2 states per year, which leave us with a 20-40% probability. The previous political-fiction scenario is just a causal pathway for this to happen, and it should not be taken too seriously (except for the purpose of entertaining ourselves, which is not a minor concern).

...et cetera.
It is not inconceivable that China will put pressure on a small debtor nation before the next UN General assembly.
Base rate since 2014 is 2% per year. Latest status of vatican - China relations is hacking done by Chinese government. More research of the other 15 countries is needed.

A two and a half month question, why? Hattip to @fisherdbus for doing the leg work and reporting on it in a generous way. Perhaps a country will accept an offer of covid immunization in return for recognition of the PRC. This would be a shrewd tradeoff for a national politician to engineer. Paraguay is wedged between two covid hot spots: Brazil and Argentina, it would appear that this would be a logical tradeoff to protect the population that may otherwise have a difficult time getting jabs. Given that the PRC has several vaccines both in trials and distribution this would seem to be a logical carrot and humane gesture.

It has happened before as two countries mentioned above dropped recognition in 2019. Paraguay is considering. https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/taiwans-last-stand-in-south-america/
Currently fifteen states recognise Taiwan as the ROC (and thus do not have official relations with Beijing): Belize, Guatemala, Haiti, Holy See, Honduras, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Nicaragua, Palau, Paraguay, St Lucia, St Kitts and Nevis, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Swaziland and Tuvalu. The Holy See is making a deal with China but its support of Taiwan will not be affected. China might try to buy off some others as covid has destroyed economies. Needs more research by checking country to country relationships.

Despite China's significant economic influence and military expansion, many countries are finding China's handling of COVID and coercive tactics with debt to struggling nations are increasingly unpalatable.  Belize, Hondurus, Nauru and Taualu have all reaffirmed their relations with Taiwan recently and official visits to Taipei by the US and Czech Republic increase their international stature for support.  If another country is to cease official recognition, it will likely be after November to assess the US stance towards Taiwan following the elections.
I can't find any indications that any countries are currently considering this. The time period is short so I'm putting a low likelihood.

Considerations:
i) China has consistently been poaching allies from Taiwan since 2016
ii) On average it has been a few each year; assuming that rate continues there is a reasonable chance they will poach another one in the timeframe. However it is probably not greater than a 30-50% chance since the timeframe is very short.
iii) US foreign policies in response may be discouraging Taiwan's allies from switching sides. For instance it's notable that after Pence cancelled a visit with the solomon islands when they recognised the PRC, the only nation to cease recognising Taiwan was Kiribati four days later (probably because it was already their plan). However it is unclear. The article below argues in some cases the policies may actually encourage nations ceasing recognition with Taiwan (though I'm not completely convinced). Nevertheless China probably will continue poaching most allies if they have enough determination given everyone's interests.
iv) With all that said this research is very scant so it's possible I don't know what I'm talking about. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7102519/
There's a fairly small number of nations that formal recognize Taiwan at the moment, and it's a fairly narrow time frame
Too early and way too complicated to predict.
On the face it seems to be an obvious "no" but ... need to research.

Low given timeframe. Winnie The Pooh has a lot on the go currently and standing in world not exactly in ascendant. Not a strong play for internal audience either. Best to bide time re Taiwan - potentially sowing discord or more amenable government from within.

There are currently only 18 nations which recognize Taiwan independence from China. Most are small, relatively insignificant players in world affairs with significant internal issues and a sizeable population of poor.  They appear particularly susceptible to Chinese inducements, much like two recent small Oceana states which dropped their recognition of Taiwan. Under an aggressive campaign to assert greater control over its perceived birth-right territories, Xi will likely take advantage of the environment within which impoverished nations can be persuaded to see things through the lens of Beijing. It does not help Taiwan that the US dropped its independent recognition of Taiwan in 1979.

Based on the small number of states that still officially recognize Taiwan (15 including the Vatican), it is unlikely that one of them would decide to cease recognition in this relatively short time period.  Per wikipedia, an average of only 1 state per year has stopped recognizing Taiwan since 2012.  A potential wildcard for this forecast would be direct diplomatic pressure by China against one of the four small island nations of Oceania that still recognize Taiwan.
